Option C is not a strong refutation because it only states that the growth stages of fish correspond to their juvenile, adult, middle-aged, and elderly stages, but it does not directly address the growth rates.

Therefore, the best option that can refute the argument is (D) "There is no obvious change in the growth cycle of Jurassic fish and modern fish." This statement directly challenges the assumption made in the argument that the growth rate of Leeds was likely to exceed that of the whale shark based on their size and lifespan. If there is no obvious change in the growth cycle of Jurassic fish and modern fish, then it is unlikely that the growth rate of Leeds was significantly faster than that of the whale shark.
